comms_internal: Same as 2, same verb as in 43, 102. Literally, this means ‘My ear does me’. The meaning is that if acute pain. Alternative is “n̄ gɔ̏ gɯ́ yɤ̏ wɯ́-sīʌ” [1SG.NSBJ head inside 3SG.EXI break] ‘My head aches’. It is only applicable to head. There are further alternatives a) along the lines of “Pepper burns my throat”, b) a special expression for stomach ache, c) “his heart is no illness on it”, d) “the wound aches”.

Same as 1, same verb as in 43, 102. Lit. ‘the disease does on him’. Alternative is the construction with the verb “lòo” (arrive) and the bha_SBJ pattern, cf. “bhlɯ̏ndhi̋ɤ yà lòo ȁ bhȁ” [smallpox 3SG.PRF arrive 3SG on] ‘he has got smallpox’; this pattern is used with skin diseases; lòo ‘come, arrive; descend’,
“gɔ̏” is a postposition, it has a wide range of uses: comitative, possessive and several further abstract meanings.

comms: Not included in the database because the intended meaning is expressed by a structurally discontinuous combination (predicate + adnominal modifier).
comms_internal: Literally, this is sth like “By Gbato there.is much money”. Possession is conveyed by an existential construction (the function of the copula is conveyed by a series of markers that can also be used in verbal sentences, the so-called «местоименные предикативные показатели», or STUMP-markers).
The main meaning of bhɔ̄: ‘to appear’.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ dháŋ̏ bhȍ Gɤ̀ɤ̏ dhi̋ɤ
comms_internal: Same as 114. CV. “bhō” is a light verb
Same verb as in 30, different pattern.
Same as 11. This is the default verb for the meaning ‘to see’. Alternative is “yɤ̄” (TR), cf. “Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ kɔ́ yɤ̏” [PN(M) 3SG.EXI house see\NEUT] ‘Gbato sees a house’.

sentence: zīi-dhɛ̏ yɤ̏ bhɛ̄n bhȁ glȅŋ bhȍ glőo
glosses_en: old-ABSTR 3SG.EXI human POSS common.sense remove\NEUT trace
comms_internal: CV. The verb “bhō” means ‘remove, take off’, followed by the noun “glőo” ‘trace’. Literally, it means ‘the old age moves the common sense from its place’.
Same as 9. Alternative is “yɤ̄” (TR). For both verbs, “kpȁn” and “yɤ̄”, there is polysemy “to see – to meet” (and also “to find”).
Same verb as in 50, 79, different patterns. The basic meaning of “dȁ” is ‘to go up’. Y is encoded either by the locative case (for declinable nouns), or by postposition “gɯ́” (for the others).
The verb “gɔ̏-kʌ̄” contains a preverb, lit. “to do head”. Alternative is “gā sɯ́” ‘to take bone’ with the SBJ_bha pattern.
Same as 74, same verb as in 15, 90.

sentence: fla̋bhīn yà gó ɤ̄ bhā dȕ ká bɯ̋
glosses_en: Pullo 3SG.PRF go.away REFL.SG POSS cow with wilderness.LOC
back_translation_en: ‘The Pullo has chased his cow to the bush.’
comms_internal: Same verb as in 14, 74, 90, different pattern. Literally, X leaves with Y (for somewhere). Pullo is an individual from the Fulbe ethnic group.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yȁ pɤ̄ Gɤ́ɤ̏ dhɛ̏ yɤ̏ dhūn ɤ̄ pi̋ɤ
glosses_en: PN(M) 3SG.EXI>3SG.NSBJ say PN(M) for 3SG.SBJV come REFL.SG at
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato told Gueu to come to him.’
comms_internal: A literal translation is “Gbato said it to Gueu to come to him (to Gbato)”.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yȁ kʌ̋ʌ kún ɤ̄ kwɛ̀ŋ̏
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato is holding a hoe in his hands.’
comms_internal: Same as 19. The basic meaning of “kún” is ‘to catch’.

back_translation_en: ‘The dog has caught (up with) the hare.’
comms_internal: Same as 18. One of the meanings of “kún” ‘catch’ is ‘catch up’.

sentence: fla̋bhīn yȁ dȕ yɔ́n yi̋ bhō
comms_internal: CV. Lit. “X has removed the water of the breast of Y”. It is not easy to determine whether Y is syntactically should be analyzed as the direct object of the complex verb or rather as an adnominal possessor associated with the breast. On somewhat arbitrary grounds, I prefer the former analysis, which makes this sentence meet the includion criteria. Pullo is an individual from the Fulbe ethnic group.

sentence: kpla̋gɔ̄ yà yɤ̄ yi̋ kpőŋ bhȁ
comms_internal: Same verb as in 55, different pattern.

sentence: ká dhɤ́ pá’ bhān mōtô ká
comms_internal: 1) In this sentence, “dhɤ́” is an auxiliary verb (for the prohibitive). 2) The instrument (hand, stick...) can appear as DO: “yȁ ɤ̄ kɔ̏ pá dhʌ́n kpōŋ̋dhɛ̏ ká” [3SG.PRF REFL.SG hand.CMM touch child forehead.CMM with] ‘he has touched child's forehead with his hand’.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ gɔ̏n gɔ̄ɔn-sīʌ Gɤ́ɤ̏ ká
comms_internal: CV. “gɔ̏n gɔ̄ɔn” ‘wage war’ is a N + V idiomatic expression.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ tœ̋œŋ̏dʌ̄-dhɛ̏ kʌ̄-sīʌ Gɤ́ɤ̏ ká
comms_internal: CV, a N + V idiomatic expression.

sentence: Zân yɤ̏ zȍ-gɔ́n-sīʌ pʌ́ yā ká
comms_internal: Same as 48. “zȍ-gɔ́n” ‘think’ is a compound verb, the first component is ‘heart’, and the second component appears only in this compound.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yȁ yúɤ̏ɤ yɛ̏ yɔ̋n ká
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato has fried some fish in oil.’

comms_internal: Alternative is the construction with the verb “dɔ̄” ‘stand’ used in the SBJ_go pattern, cf. “dɔ̄ n̄ gɔ̏” [stand 1SG.NSBJ head] ‘Wait for me (standing)’.

comms: Not included in the database because X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
sentence: Gbȁtȍ zȍ yȁ bhɔ̄ fɛ̂tɤ̏ wɔ̏n ká
glosses_en: PN(M) heart 3SG.PRF appear holiday matter\IZF with
comms_internal: CV

sentence: ȁ sɔ̄nŋ yɤ̏ sɯ̏ ȁ kʌ̏gbɛ́sɯ̏ bhȁ
comms_internal: Same verb as in 8, different pattern. The basic meaning of the verb “sɯ́” is ‘to take’.
Same verb as in 51, different pattern.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ Gɤ̀ɤ̏ dɔ̏ kwɛ̏ ɤ́ zȉɤ yā ȁ ká
glosses_en: PN(M) 3SG.EXI PN(M) know\NEUT year REL\3SG.JNT pass\JNT here 3SG.NSBJ with
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato got acquainted with Gueu last year.’
comms_internal: Same as 33. The meanings ‘to know, to be acquainted with’ and ‘to get acquainted with’ are not distinguished lexically.

sentence: bhɛ̄n dódó dhʌ̀n wó dhɤ̄ kwànbhɛ̏n bhā dɔ̄’
glosses_en: human rare FOC 3PL.JNT go\JNT theft human\IZF ART know\INF
comms_internal: Same as 32.
Same as 105. The main meaning of this verb is ‘to kill; to beat’. There is another verb for ‘play a wind instrument’.
Same verb as in 85, different pattern. “kpɔ́” is a very polysemic verb, the basic meaning is ‘spread’.
The verb contains a preverb. The verb also means ‘to fix, to repare’.

sentence: Yɔ̏ yȁ wɛ̀ɛ dɔ̄ Gɤ̀ɤ̏ bhȁ
comms_internal: CV. Alternative is the complex verb “ye̋e tó” [laughter remain] with the same pattern, cf. “Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ ye̋e tó-sīʌ Gɤ̀ɤ̏ bhȁ” [PN(M) 3SG.EXI laughter remain-DUR PN(M) on] ‘Gbato is laughing at Gueu’.

comms: Non-verbal predicate.
comms_internal: Same verb as 87, 100, 121, different patterns. “gɔ̏” is a postposition derived from the noun ‘head’.
CV. The original meaning of the expression “yɔ̋ɔ zīɤ” is ‘whitewash (a house, a wall)’, but it seems to have broadened, and nowadays it can also be used for painting with a paint.
CV. Lit. ‘catch with teeth’. “sɔ̋ɔn” is a comitative case form of “sɔ̋n” ‘tooth, teeth’. “sɔ̋ɔn” can be omited if the context is sufficiently clear.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: The informant tend to translate the stimul with expressions like “X has no Y” or “X has run bankrupt”.
Same as 102, same verb as in 1, 2. Same as 102, same verb as in 1, 2. The basic meaning of the verb “kʌ̄” is ‘to do’.

comms: This sentence is semantically slightly different from the stimulus.
sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ dhīaŋ dhɛ̋ɛndhɛ̋ɛn zʌ̄-sīʌ Yɔ̏ dhɛ̏
glosses_en: PN(M) 3SG.EXI talk tasty.INT.PL kill-DUR PN(F) for
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato is saying pleasant words to Yo.’
comms_internal: CV. It is a descriptive expression, ‘to say pleasant words’.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: CV. Literally, this means ‘Yo’s love chases/pursues Gbato’. The verb “kʌ̄” has basic meaning ‘to do’, but it this particular expression, my inormants translate it as ‘chase’. This expression also means ‘to like’ and ‘want, wish’.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ sʌ́ʌdhɛ̋ bhìinbhi̋in-kʌ̄-sīʌ Yɔ̏ dhɛ̏
back_translation_en: ‘Gbato is waving a piece of paper in front of Yo.’
comms_internal: This verb contains a preverb.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yɤ̏ ɤ̄ zȍ-gɔ́n-sīʌ gɔ̄ dȅe ká
glosses_en: PN(M) 3SG.EXI REFL.SG heart-operate-DUR vehicle new with
comms_internal: Same as 25. The verb “zȍ-gɔ́n” means both ‘think about sth.’ and ‘dream about’, these two meanings are not really distinguished. The verbal stem “gɔ́n” appears only in this preverbial verb.

sentence: Yɤ̏ bhān sɔ̄ dhɔ̀ɔ ȁ zȕ bhɛ̄ntīi sāȁ ká
glosses_en: 3SG.EXI 1SG.POSS cloth ART 3SG.NSBJ wash/NEUT human black soap with
back_translation_en: ‘She has washed my clothes with black soap.’

comms_internal: Same verb as in 12, 79, different patterns.

Same verb as in 31, different pattern. Lit. “they call her Mary”. 3PL subject is currently used for impersonal subject; but a personal subject (‘We call her Mary’, etc.) is also possible. The syntactic status of the name Mary is not very clear: it is not DO (in Dan, DO precedes the verb, without any exception). Probably, it is an indirect object, although the latter is normally introduced by a postposition (although, in some expressions, postposition may be missing). Alternative is construction with unusual and not fully clear syntactic properties. It includes the verb “kʌ̄” ‘do’ and the following structure: “wȍ ȁ Màdhî kʌ̏” [3PL.EXI 3SG.NSBJ Mary do\NEUT] ‘It’s her who is named Mary’. Superficially, at least, both X and Y are in the DO slot (sequence: X Y). But this expression is not basic for the meaning ‘call smb’.
This verb contains a preverb. This verb is used for a mild in-family punishment (e.g., a father to a child); not about sentences and prisons.
Same verb as in 86, different pattern. The basic meaning of the verb is ‘to fall’.
A spontaneous action, not passive.

Finding as a result of a search. The basic meaning of the verb is ‘to see’. Alternative is the construction with the verb “kpȁn” with the SBJ_bha pattern, cf. “Gbȁtȍ yȁ kpȁn làkle̋e bhȁ” [PN(M) 3SG.PRF see key on] ‘Gbato has found a key’. It is Same verb as in 21, different pattern. This pattern is used if finding is not a result of a special search (he occasionally found a key lost by someone else). The basic meaning of the verb is ‘to see’.

comms: Not included in the database because X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.

comms_internal: Literally ‘One hundred francs is lacking in Gbato’s money’.

sentence: sɔ̄ búʌ̏ŋbȕʌŋ dȁ dhɔ̏ yɤ̏ bhʌ̄nŋ́-dhȕn kʌ̏

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: CV. Lit. ‘The need of clothes catches me’. Alternative is a non-verbal construction like “sɔ̄ kplȁ yɤ̏ n̄ bhȁ” [cloth need 3SG.EXI 1SG.NSBJ on] ‘I need clothes’, lit. ‘The need for clothes is on me’. It also cannot be included because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier. One more alternative is another non-verbal construction, cf. “n̄ bhȁnwɔ̏n yɤ̏ glɔ̄ɔ bhȁ” [1SG.NSBJ need 3SG.EXI banana on] ‘I need bananas’. Again, it cannot be included (X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier).

sentence: sa̋an yɤ̏ klʌ̀ʌn-sɯ̏ ká pɤ̂ zɯ̏
back_translation_en: ‘The village is surrounded by a rampart.’
comms_internal: The postposition “ká” is a part of the resultative construction (verb in the Gerund form + “ká”), it does not introduce arguments.

sentence: Gbȁtȍ yȁ wʌ́ʌ̏gā gbàn sēȅ, gblɯ̋ plɛ̀ dhʌ̀n yȁ tó ȁ gɔ̏

back_translation_en: ‘Gbato has wasted all the money, he only has 1,000 francs left.’

The basic meaning of “ka̋n” is ‘to cut’.
The noun “ta̋n” means both ‘dance’ and ‘song’ (its meaning depends on the verb: “bhō” for ‘sing’, and “kʌ̄” for ‘dance’).
CV

sentence: ɯ̄ bhā sɛ̄ŋtíȕ yɤ̏ dhȉ ɯ̄ bhā sɔ̄ ká

back_translation_en: ‘Your belt goes well with your outfit.’
comms_internal: The basic meaning of “dhī” is ‘to crop well’, in other context it means ‘please; satisfy; be pretty; turn favourable’.
Same as 14, same verb as in 15, 90. With this verb, Y can be also introduced by various postpositions with locative meaning (it depends on the starting position of X).

Same as 93. The basic meaning of the verb is ‘hear’. An alternative is “gɯ́-bhān”, lit. “inside-hear”, also with the pattern TR.

comms_internal: CV. The word for ‘heart’ comes from “zū-wɛ̋ɛ̋” ‘hear-grain’. Эта форма обязательна во многих идиоматических выражениях.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
sentence: pɤ̂ kpíȉ wɔ̏n yȁ ȁ kɔ́n
back_translation_en: ‘He was surprised by the big city.’
comms_internal: Lit. ‘The matter of a big city astonished him’.

sentence: Yɔ̏ yɤ̏ ɤ̄ gwāȁnkpɔ́yɔ̋ɔ sȁn kʌ̄-sīʌ
comms_internal: CV. “sȁn kʌ̄” means both ‘despise’ and ‘hate’. It is difficult to detemine whether Y is encoded as the possessor of the direct object, or rather it is the direct object in a construction with a complex predicate. On somewhat arbitrary grounds, I take the second option, which makes this sentence meet the inclusion criteria.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
sentence: Yɔ̏ wɔ̏n yȁ bhán Gbȁtȍ ká
comms_internal: In Dan, one cannot say ‘He is upset because of Y’; it is obligatory to say ‘because of the matter of Y’, and this pattern occurs in many expressions. Alternative is the construction with the verb “dȁ” “Gbȁtȍ zūʌ̋ dhìn yáa dȁ-sɯ̏ ká ȁ gbɤ̄ wɔ̏n gɯ́” [PN(M) heart soul 3SG.NEG.IPFV go.up-GER with 3SG.NSBJ son matter\IZF in] ‘Gbato is sad because of his son's matters’, which also cannot be included because both X and Y are expressed as NP-internal modifiers.

sentence: wɔ́n yà sȉɤ ȁ dhɛ̏ dȅdȅwō

sentence: yɤ̏ yɤ̋ŋ sɯ̏ ȁ bhȁ klɤ̄ɤ̏-dhɛ̏ wɔ̏n gɯ́
glosses_en: 3SG.EXI diffidence take\NEUT 3SG.NSBJ POSS short-ABSTR matter\IZF in
back_translation_en: ‘He is embarrassed about his small height.’
comms_internal: CV. Lit. ‘He takes diffidence in the matter of his shortness’.
